answers.answer: Your doctor is pretty much correct. Good luck to you!
Yes, normally the success rate for genotype 1 is 50%. If you have also HIV, it is 30%.

With SOC and geno 1's, percentage is between 40 - 50 percent.  There are other factors that lower the odds such as existing medical conditions like diabetes, advanced liver disease, age, gender to name a few.If you become UND within the first 4 weeks the odds go up.If you become UND by 12 wks, the odds stay within the 40 - 50 percent.  If you don't clear the virus by 12 wks, you are considered a slow repsonder, the odds go down and treatment extention to 72 wks is recommended.

I have genotype 1a - before treatment my viral load was 2.7 million - at my 6 week viral check it was 12 - at my 12th week check it is non-detectable - my enzymes have been holding steady at 10 since week 4 - I know I'm not out of the woods yet as there is always a chance it can come back - I'm on week 30/48 - my nurse and my doctor both have told me that my genotype is the most difficult to cure but at the same time they are quite impressed with how well I'm responding to the treatment - they told me that since I only had it for less than a year when I was diagnosed is probably one reason why I'm doing so well - I also had no damage what-so-ever to my liver.  there is hope for success for us 1a's - but one of the main things is to remain positive and laugh as much as you can.
Thanks for the comments. Good luck to you all.

question: I've read an awful lot of posts here (great, helpful site) about the odds of treatment with pegasys and ribavirin. My own Dr. quoted about a 50% success rate. But I've read here that genotype 1 is the hardest to get cleared. Does anyone know what the odds for success are for genotype 1? By the way, I do not know if I'm 1a or whatever. Only that I'm a 1.
title: Just What Are the ODDS?
